content.text: Describe how to use the apparatus in Fig. 1.1 to take two measurements to determine the diameter \(d\) of the ball. You may draw on Fig. 1.1 to help your description.
Using the blocks as shown in Fig. 1.1, take two measurements to determine the diameter \(d\) of the ball.
Use your measurements to calculate a value for the diameter \(d\) of the ball. Show your working.
Place the ball between the two blocks as seen from above in Fig. 1.1.
Calculate the volume \(V\) of the ball using the equation \(V=0.52d^{3}\).
Include the unit.
Use the balance to measure the mass \(m_{\mathrm{D}}\) of the dish provided.
Place the ball in the dish and record the combined mass \(m_{\mathrm{C}}\) of the dish and the ball.
Calculate the mass \(m_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the ball. Show your working.
Calculate the density \(\rho\) of the ball using the equation:
Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment.
[Total: 11]
In this experiment, you will determine the density of a ball.
Use the thermometer to measure the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the water in the container labelled 'cold water'.
\(V\) is the total volume of water in beaker \(\mathbf{A}\).
Complete the column headings in Table 2.1.
\(\cdot\) Pour \(100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of hot water into beaker \(\mathbf{A}\).
\(\cdot\) Place the thermometer in the hot water in beaker \(\mathbf{A}\).
\(\cdot\) Record in Table 2.1 the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water.
\(\cdot\) Without delay, use the measuring cylinder to add \(20 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of the cold water to the water in beaker \(\mathbf{A}\).
\(\cdot\) Stir the water in beaker \(\mathbf{A}\).
\(\cdot\) Record in Table 2.1 the temperature of the mixture of hot and cold water.
\(\cdot\) Repeat the procedure, adding \(20 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of cold water each time, until you have a total of \(200 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of water in beaker \(\mathbf{A}\).
Plot a graph of temperature \(\theta(y\)-axis) against total volume of water \(V(x\)-axis). You do not need to start the axes at the origin \((0,0)\).
Draw the best-fit curve.
[Total: 11]
[Turn over
Suggest two ways to minimise the loss of thermal energy from the beaker during the experiment.
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of hot water in a beaker. Refer to Fig. 2.1.
Draw a line below MR, 10.0 cm long from B at an angle of incidence \(i=40^{\circ}\) to the normal and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line A.
Place the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line MR.

Place two pins, \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\), on line AB at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment. Label the positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\).

View the images of pins \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1. Place two pins, \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\), so that pins \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\) and the images of \(\mathrm{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) all appear exactly one behind the other. Label the positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\).

Draw a line 10.0 cm long near the middle of the ray-trace sheet. Label the line MR. Draw a normal to this line that passes through its centre. Label the normal NL. Label the point at which NL crosses MR with the letter B.
Remove the pins and the mirror. Draw a line through the positions of \(\mathrm{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{4}\). Continue the line until it meets MR.
Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between this line and the normal NL. An acute angle is an angle less than \(90^{\circ}\).
Draw a line below MR, 10.0 cm long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(i=50^{\circ}\) to the normal and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{C}\).
Turn the ray-trace sheet through \(180^{\circ}\). See Fig. 3.2.
Suggest a relationship between \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\). Justify your answer by reference to the results.
[Total: 11]
BLANK PAGE
State two techniques that you use to obtain an accurate ray trace.
In this experiment, you will investigate the position of the image in a plane mirror.
Use the ray-trace sheet supplied, referring to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on your ray-trace sheet. Tie your ray-trace sheet into this question booklet between pages 8 and 9.
A student investigates the relationship between the diameter and the resistance of wires.
The following apparatus is available:
· wires with different diameters
· instrument for measuring the diameter of a wire
· metre ruler
· ammeter
· voltmeter
· power supply.
Other apparatus normally found in a school laboratory is also available.
Plan an experiment to investigate how the diameter of a wire affects its resistance.
Resistance \(R\) is given by the equation \(R=\frac{V}{I}\), where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire.
You are **not** required to do this investigation. You do **not** need to write about safety precautions.
In your plan:
· draw a circuit diagram to show the circuit you use
· explain briefly how to do the investigation
· state **one** key variable to keep constant
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
· explain how to use your results to reach a conclusion.
BLANK PAGE
